Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Shedding Light on Viral Dark Matter - Genetic, Taxonomic, and Functional Diversity of Coral Reef Viromes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Viruses are the most abundant, most diverse, and least understood biological entities on Earth. It is very likely that the most common organism on the planet is a virus that is currently unknown to science. Because viruses reproduce within a host cell they can have enormous impacts on the well being of the host and possess genes that are integral to the host's ability to carry out important biological functions, such as photosynthesis in marine environments. A major goal of this research project is to develop novel, high-throughput methods to rapidly reveal and characterize the diversity of this biological 'dark matter'. First, the size of the global viral gene pool will be determined by analyzing viral DNAs from the world's major biomes. The work will then focus on the viruses of coral reefs by examining the most abundant viral proteins and determining their functions using genetics and protein structures. Combined and integrated, these approaches will address the genetic, functional, and taxonomic dimensions of viral biodiversity.

Discoveries stemming from the study of viruses have been at the forefront of many breakthroughs in biological research. Values to society from this specific work will include more comprehensive knowledge of global viral biodiversity and of the role of viruses in the health of coral reefs, valuable ecosystems that are under considerable stress due to climate change and other human activities. It is expected that this research will fundamentally alter our understanding of the interactions of viruses and the biodiversity of the planet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project allowed for the collection of the viruses inhabiting coral reefs across the world. From these collections, viromes (genetic make-up of viruses) were constructed to characterize the viral diversity associated with coral reefs influenced by varying degrees of degradation due to over fishing and other human interactions. The collections were also shared with a researcher in Israel who is searching for the presence of viral photosynthetic genes. Photosynthetic genes help capture the sun’s energy for coral to survive and grow.

 

 

An additional aim of the research was to determine if there were new viruses developing on the coral reefs and the surrounding areas. Metagenomics (the study of genetic material recovered directly from environmental samples) and metaproteomics (the study of proteins in environmental samples) were used to identify novel viruses. Using artificial neural networks (ANNs, which estimate or approximate functions similar to brain function), we were able to predict the protein function without relying on sequence similarities to already known viruses. This techniques allowed us to discover several viral proteins previously unknown (Figure 1).

 

 

The final aim of the research was to characterize unknown viral genes that likely encode metabolic functions. Bacterial viruses play a large role modulating bacterial populations in nature. Metabolomics (the scientific study of the set of metabolites present within an organism, cell, or tissue) was used to provide a complementary view of host metabolism during expression of our novel phage genes.

 

The main objective for this project was to enhance scientific knowledge of viruses. Our greatest success in achieving this objective was our publication of the first Phage Atlas, Life in Our Phage World: A centennial field guide to the Earth's most diverse inhabitants

This book provides a glimpse of the rich and diverse phage (short for bacteriophage which is a virus that infects and replicates within a bacterium) life that has been sampled over the past one hundred years (Figure 2). The overall organization of the book parallels the phage life cycle. It starts with virions on the prowl, observes them as their genome enters and takes over a host cell, describes their replication, then concludes as the progeny virions assemble and make their escape into the world. For each stage we chose a few diverse phages to feature.
